conclusion: To determine the temperature of the gas at state B, use the ideal gas law and properties of the processes.
From state A to state B, the volume remains constant (VA = VB). This is an isochoric process.
The ideal gas law is PV = nRT.
Since the volume is constant, PA/TA = PB/TB.
Rearrange the equation to solve for TB: TB = TA x (PB/PA).
Substitute the known values: TB = 300 K x (1 x 10^5 Pa / 3 x 10^5 Pa) = 100 K.
The temperature of the gas at state B is 100 K.
